rollout:
The options are glutamic acid to lysine, leucine to alanine, etc., up to valine to glutamic acid.

First, I remember that each codon has an amino acid and a corresponding codon in the genetic code. For example, glutamic acid (Glu) codes for Asp (Asn), which is one of the first six codons (I, II, III, IV, V, VI). So changing Glu to Lys (Leu) would require substituting the Asp to Lys.

Wait, but maybe I'm mixing up the positions. Let me think again. Each codon corresponds to a specific amino acid based on the genetic code. If I start with Glu, it's position I (I, II, III, IV, V, VI), so it uses codons 1-6. Changing to Leu, which is position II, uses codons 7-8. So to go from Glu to Leu, you'd have to substitute at least two bases because they're in different codons. Maybe more if there are multiple substitutions needed across the chain.

Similarly, leucine to alanine—Leu (II) to Asn (I). Since Leu uses codons 7-8, and Asn is codon 9, you might have to change several codons here as well.

Phenylalanine (Phe) is position III (IV, V, VI, VII, VIII, IX), so it uses codons 4-9. To change Phe to Gly (Gly), which is position IV (V, VI, VII, VIII, IX, X), you'd have to adjust these codons too.

Valine (Val) is position V (VI, VII, VIII, IX, X, XI), using codons 5-11. Changing Val to Glu would involve moving into codons that use Gln (XIII), so you'd have substitutions here as well.

Each of these changes likely requires multiple substitutions because the codons are in different positions. So, perhaps each conversion involves changing several codons, leading to multiple substitutions per amino acid change.
</think>
The correct answer is A

prefix_without_chunk: Okay, so I need to figure out the minimum number of base substitutions required to change codons from various amino acids to others.
chunk_resampled: Let's break down each part:
rollout:
Let's break down each part:

a) Glutamic acid to lysine.

Glutamic acid is one of the conserved cysteine residues in the N-terminus of proteins. Lysine is the basic amino acid at the C-terminus of the arginine-amino valine loop. To go from glutamic acid (Glu) to lysine (Lys), we have to substitute the Gln residue because Glu and Lys are both involved in forming the arginine-amino valine loop in proteins.

So, substitution count here is 1.

b) Leucine to alanine.

Leucine (Leu) is a conserved cysteine found in the side chain of arginine. Alanine (Ala) is the simplest amino acid. In proteins, arginine forms an amide bond with alanine through a conserved peptide bond. Therefore, substituting Leu with Ala requires just 1 substitution.

c) Phenylalanine to glycine.

Phenylalanine (Phe) is another conserved cysteine. Glycine (Gly) is similar but has a carboxylic acid group instead of an amide. The conversion involves changing Phe to Gly. This typically requires a single substitution because they're structurally very similar and can be converted into each other via peptide bonds.

d) Tryptophane to serine.

Starting with a): Glutamic acid is Gln, and lysine is Lys. Both are alpha-amino acids. To convert Gln to Lys, you can either mutate the third carbon (changing arginine to asparagine) or mutate the second carbon (asparagine to lysine). Alternatively, you could also mutate both the second and third carbons. But since the goal is to minimize substitutions, perhaps mutating two positions isn't necessary because mutating the third position alone might suffice. Wait, no—mutating the third carbon of arginine (which is arginine to asparagine) then mutating the second carbon from asparagine to lysine would actually result in lysine. That's two substitutions. Alternatively, mutating the fourth carbon of tyrosine (if you start from tyrosine instead of tyrosine to asparagine to alanine). Either way, it's one substitution.

That's three substitutions.
